Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 09:03PM Misawa47 wrote: Hi Erica, I just have to post here to say how shocked I am that a doctor would say that to you. Would he give his mother the same advice??? I do hope you go back to the BS and get an MRI at the least. You don't want to ignore this, especially since it has grown over the past 2 months. don't let this arrogant doctor throw you off track. You are your own advocate for your health. My prayers are with you. Bernice
Posts.Title: Appt at comprehensive breast clinic... What to ask? ecm kayakgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2009 10:19PM Misawa47 wrote: Hi Lynn, where do you live at in Japan? I am at Misawa which is about 450 miles north of Tokyo. Even going to Okinawa is expensive. All flights go out of the Narita Airport in Tokyo which means I have to either fly or take the bullet train which costs $250/each way then the airline ticket is the same to Okinawa or Hawaii. I am going on a business trip to Okinawa in April so could see about seeing a doctor while I am there. Actually the doctor I saw here about the mass ordered an x-ray for me; however, I don't believe the bone itself has changed and that is all the x-ray will see is the bone. The Radiology department agreed that an x-ray will not see tissue. I was actually hoping for a ct scan. How are you doing? Bernice

Posts.Content: Misawa47 wrote: I haven't found this topic covered and may not pertain to the breast cancer board, but I can't help but think there may be a connection. I have a 3" wide hard mass along my 1st rib on the left side. It started in Dec and has steadily grown where it obviously protrudes. I did have microcalcifications and 2 stereotactic biopsy's on that breast which came back B9. I still have a very sore enlarged lymph node under my armpit that has been dismissed by every doctor I have seen under my left armpit. If anyone has experienced this, please post to relieve my anxiety. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 04:59PM Misawa47 wrote: Hi ravdeb, I had an MRI where they found a 6mm mass. The doctor recommended an ultrasound and a biopsy "just to make sure". I have to travel for procedures; however, my local hospital here can perform the ultrasound. My long-distance doctor said that if the ultrasound did not reveal the mass as something other than a cyst, he would like to perform another MRI in 6 months to see if there are any changes. I would at the very least request an MRI in 6 months to watch this "thingy" "just in case" .
Posts.Title: MRI false negatives? worried4sis marie5890

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 04:44AM Misawa47 wrote: Liz - I am 47 and had an abnormal mammogram Jul 08 which showed a cluster of microcalcifications in my left breast.  I live in northern Japan and the medical hospital is not equipped with performing breast biopsy's. I had to fly to Atlanta GA in Aug 08 for a stereotactic biopsy; however, the Dr missed the spot. I, then, had to fly to Hawaii in Nov 08 for another stereotactic biopsy. Came back b9; however, the Oncologist reading the report wanted me to have an MRI done due to my family history of ovarian cancer (mom and sister). I found out the end of Dec that there was a 6mm mass in the RIGHT breast! The doctor strongly recommended an ultrasound and a biopsy. It is extremely expensive for me to travel for these medical procedures and it is all out of pocket. I am retired military but they don't cover travel, food and lodging, only free medical.  I have also read about the many false positives from an MRI so elected to wait 6 months then fly back to Hawaii for another MRI for changes. The Oncologist from Hawaii called my office last Wednesday, 14 Jan, urgently telling me to get the ultrasound "just to be safe" ASAP. I didn't know doctors makes those calls to patients long distance, and does he know something more than I know? I am so paranoid and scared. I spoke to the medical facility here (Northern Japan) and after my films arrive back here in Japan, they will schedule me for an ultrasound and even if they find something they don't have the equipment or the expertise to perform a biopsy. My concern is that I have very dense breast so what if it doesn't show up and I get a false negative from the ultrasound?  If you are able to get the biopsy,  I would definitely do it based on the stories I have read from other women. Mine is a financial reason to hold off.
Posts.Title: Dense Tissue & Cysts....MRI? Liz1969 Liz1969

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 08:19AM Misawa47 wrote: I am an American living in Misawa Japan. I had a mammogram that showed microcalcifications in my left breast. I traveled to Atlanta Georgia in Aug 08 to have a stereotactic biopsy done; however, they were sampling the wrong area in my breast and didn't get any microcalcifications. I now leave tomorrow for ANOTHER stereoactic biopsy in Hawaii that will be done on 21 Nov. It is very expensive for me to travel for medical procedures; however, the American doctor here says there is no Japanese doctor that can render treatment/tests. Where do you live that you have such great care? If they find something malignant in Hawaii, there is no way I can afford to stay in a hotel for a long stay and get treatment. I don't even know where to start to look for a doctor in Japan. Any advice? I don't mind traveling as far as Tokyo if I need to for care if it comes to that. I'm really nervous.
Posts.Title: Follow Up bikkuri Misawa47

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2008 06:11PM Misawa47 wrote: Hi ladies, I am retired military and my husband is a contractor. I get free medical at a military base; however, I have to pay out of pocket for travel and hotel expenses to get to these places. Of course Tri-Care covered part of the expense to see the Emory Cancer Institute in Atlanta; however, I still had to pay air fare and hotel.  Great news...my biposy results were benign. I had such a horrible stereotactic biopsy in Atlanta where they weren't able to numb me and they were still able to get 12 samples with me in excruciating pain.  I vowed I would never have another stereotactic biopsy done; however, when I learned they missed the spot, my doctor here at Misawa insisted I go to Hawaii for ANOTHER stereotactic. I was a nervous wreck. Of course, I could have seen a doctor locally with a referral; however, I would have to pay a percentage where if I went to a military hospital I didn't have to pay anything so I elected to to to Trippler Army Medical Hospital in Hawaii. I took a Xantax prior to the procedure as I was so concerned they wouldn't be able to numb me as before. They gave me 10cc of lidocaine and I didn't feel a thing! This was done on a Friday (21 Nov) and I went for the results on the following Wednesday. The doctor then examined me and felt 2 lumps in the other breast (right) that they were concerned with so insisted that I have an MRI before heading back to Misawa. The doctor that performed the biopsy did an Ultrasound on the lumps but didn't see anything to be concerned with. However, the second doctor said a mammogram AND an ultrasound can miss a lot. Due to Thanksgiving, I wasn't able to get in until the following Monday (1 Dec) and they MRI'd both breasts to "make sure". I understand it will take about a week for the pictures to be reviewed.  The doctors/staff at Trippler were amazing. They were very knowledgeable and spent a great deal of time explaining to me every step. I actually was able to get a room at Trippler Lodging; however, it was so far from the city and there were no eating establishments within walking distance that I ended up moving to the Hale Koa Hotel. Fumi, thanks so much for your information. I have been inquiring about specialist in Japan but was told there are no cancer specialist in Japan. This was from my surgeon here at Misawa! I will keep this information and pass it on to other people here at Misawa and for myself if needed in the future. I heard the past wing commander's wife that just left here this past summer, was just diagnosed with stage 4 breast cancer. So sad. She just had a baby and has other small children. Vicky, I agree with you, it would be nice to have a site dedicated to give people information in their area about clinics/specialists, etc. I can't believe you are getting "ignored" on your symptoms. It sounds really serious. You know your body best and I would be persistent with getting an MRI. My mother has cancer for the 3rd time now. The first time was stomach cancer and they kept telling her it was nothing. She knows her body so well so went to another doctor insisting that something is not right. That is when they found the stomach cancer. She then got ovarian cancer and now fighting cancer for a 3rd time in her stomach area. You are right that if there is something, they key is to catch it early. I will keep you in my prayers. God Bless all, Bernice
Posts.Title: Follow Up bikkuri Misawa47

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 07:55PM Misawa47 wrote: Hi, I am 47 and have dense breasts as well. I had mammogram that showed microcal that were biopsied and showed b9. I have 2 lumps in my other breast that did not show on mammogram or ultrasound; however the MRI ended up identifying a small 6mm mass. The doctor wants to have it ultrasounded again and biopsied. I live in a remote area of Japan so I have to travel very far to have procedures done (Hawaii). This is very expensive. My question is if I do nothing and they do another MRI in 6 months, if it is something would it have gotten larger? I have heard of so many stories of ladies preparing for the MRI or Ultrasound-guided biopsy's only for the doctor to send them home as the tumor "disappeared". I also know MRI's provide many false-positives so would rather "wait and see"; however, if it is something I am scared that my waiting may jeopardize my health. Bernice
